usage: A container that opens to reveal storage space for holding items
interactivity: Users should feel the lid's pivoting motion with smooth arc-based movement, potential resistance from internal springs or friction.
temperature: The brass handle may feel cool to the touch
interactionDeduction: Users will approach the chest and wrap their fingers around the brass handle using a cylindrical (power) grip, likely with one hand but optionally two if extra leverage is desired. With the handle gripped, they apply an upward and backward lifting force, pivoting the lid on its hinges. As they lift, they will feel the lid’s weight shift through the hinge, along with subtle friction or spring resistance at the pivot. Once open, they can hold the lid in place or close it by reversing the motion, feeling the same arc-based motion transmitted through the handle.

inertia: The hammer should convey significant weight concentrated in the metal head, creating a distinctly top-heavy feel. Users would expect substantial resistance when lifting and notable momentum during swinging motions.
interactionDeduction: Users will grasp the hammer’s thick cylindrical handle in a full-hand power grip, fingers wrapping completely around near the end of the handle to maximize leverage. They will raise the hammer by flexing the wrist, elbow, and shoulder, sensing the top-heavy inertia of the metal head. During a swing, momentum builds in the head and transmits down the handle into the user’s hand. On impact, users experience a brief but distinct resistance and vibration traveling through the grip, followed by the hammer head’s rebound as they decelerate the motion.

usage: Optical viewing device for magnifying distant objects
outline: Users should feel the distinct dual-barrel shape
interactionDeduction: Users will pick up the binoculars with both hands, each hand cradling one barrel in a light cylindrical grip. Thumbs rest underneath and fingers wrap around the outside. The index finger and thumb of their right hand will pinch the central focus knob, rotating it in small, precise turns. They will raise the binoculars to their eyes, aligning the eyepieces, and hold them stable with slight muscle tension in the forearms and shoulders. During use they may also adjust the hinge by gently squeezing the barrels inward or outward to fine-tune eye spacing.

usage: This wheel would be used for manually operating industrial valves
interactivity: A freely rotatable structure around its central axis, responding smoothly to applied rotational forces. Users should feel the wheel's rotation transmitted through their grip points.
interactionDeduction: Users grasp the rim of the wheel with one or both hands in an over-hand or under-hand power grip, fingers or palms contacting the circular edge or spokes. They apply opposing torques—pushing forward on one side and pulling back on the other—to rotate the wheel smoothly around its central axis. As they turn, they feel continuous, low-friction rotation transmitted through their grip, with subtle resistance from the valve mechanism. If more force is needed, they may grip the spokes individually to gain extra leverage and twist further.
